body.p: Holmes probably ere this will have told you of my return to Middlesex. I received from him as a present from you two pair of razors, two pair of scissors and four penknives. I picked up a handsome set of razors as a present from a Hair Dresser of Liverpool, so I am quite rich again, and I take care to distribute your razors among some of the best chins in the country.

I have been passing my time usefully since the Association Week in Newcastle upon Tyne. My chief stand has been made in Carlisle this autumn, where and with Annan, I spent two months. I find that I kept [[2]] not a month too long for my health's sake as I broke down altogether in Manchester. I must now keep by the fireside for two or three months and nurse myself carefully ; though I mean to write much on politics and theology. Whatever I print you shall see. I send you now some of the principal placards I printed during this trip ; but I have not saved you all. I have gained no newspaper notice worth sending you. The Cumberland Packet, a Whitehaven Paper, the Tory Lord Lonsdale's Paper, fell foul of me, and went so far as to say that I undertook to Lecture on Teetotalism but got drunk before hand and disappointed the audience. A vagabond of the name of Hawthorn had made a boast of this, he began to abuse me before [[3]] an audience in Cockermouth, I mentioned his own statement to the audience and the Tory made the anecdote apply to me.

I shall be quite willing to visit Sheffield in the Spring, not fearing but I shall make it pay there. My warfare with the Socialists will excited a keen interest there ; for I teaze them every where ; looking at their calculated future as nothing but a superstition. I made way powerfully against them in Liverpool.
I hear your daughters are Social Festivalists. I have no objection to that ; and cannot but allow that in their retrospect of the present state of society they work usefully.
We are all well here. Mrs C. joined me in Carlisle and lectured on Phrenology ; also at Annan and in the summer at Gravesend and in London once.

[[4]] I was really triumphant in Carlisle. The People demanded that some of the preachers should meet me. Every one was asked and declined. In despair, a messenger was sent to Annan to Mr Ward whose letter, I enclose. He came boasting in the Market Place that he was about to meet in the theatre and to silence one of the adversaries of the Lord. I gave him such a discourse to deal with as he could not touch ; but altogether complimented it, declaring in the theatre, that he altogether approved it. I reminded him that I had superseded his historical christianity. That was a difficulty for which he required time ; which is the allusion of his letter. He was angry at my going to his place Annan. I cannot explain all of it here; but it was most interesting.
I want another Roberts on Gipsies, [of?] which I apprised Holmes.
